qas.question: Whose technology did Apple take advantage of when introducing the Macintosh II?
How much did the Macintosh II sell for?
What marked the start of a new direction for Macintosh?
What was the Macintosh II's new modular design similar to?
Whose technology did Apple take advantage of when introducing the Macintosh I?
How much did the Macintosh I sell for?
What marked the end of a new direction for Macintosh
What was the Macintosh I's new modular design similar to?

context: Updated <b5_0>Motorola<b5_0/> CPUs made a faster machine possible, and in 1987 Apple took advantage of the new <a0_0>Motorola<a0_0/> technology and introduced the Macintosh II at <a2_0><b7_0>$5500<b7_0/><a2_0/>, powered by <a1_0><b6_0>a 16 MHz Motorola 68020 processor<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The primary improvement in the Macintosh II was Color QuickDraw in ROM, a color version of the graphics language which was the heart of the machine. Among the many innovations in Color QuickDraw were the ability to handle any display size, any color depth, and multiple monitors. <a3_0>The <b8_0>Macintosh II<b8_0/><a3_0/> marked the start of a new direction for the Macintosh, as now for the first time it had an open architecture with several NuBus expansion slots, support for color graphics and external monitors, and a modular design similar to that of <a4_0>the <b9_0>IBM PC<b9_0/><a4_0/>. It had an internal hard drive and a power supply with a fan, which was initially fairly loud. One third-party developer sold a device to regulate fan speed based on a heat sensor, but it voided the warranty. Later Macintosh computers had quieter power supplies and hard drives.
